content.webTitle: Alan Pardew a manager in a maelstrom as Newcastle open gates to Hull | Louise Taylor

fields.headline: Alan Pardew a manager in a maelstrom as Newcastle open gates to Hull
fields.bodyText: A perfect storm is set to hit Newcastle United and Alan Pardew seems certain to be trapped at its epicentre. An extraordinary confluence of adverse events dictates that Pardew’s first meeting with David Meyler since he head-butted the Hull City midfielder in March appears unlikely to prove anything more than the merest footnote to events at St James’ Park on Saturday. Equipped with numerous banners and placards, Newcastle fans are planning assorted anti-Pardew protests before, during and after Hull’s visit. With his job very much on the line, the 53-year-old’s mood is unlikely to be soothed by the presence of Steve Bruce and Hatem Ben Arfa in the adjacent dugout. While Bruce would reportedly not be averse to swapping his role in charge of the visitors for Pardew’s office, Ben Arfa could easily become a focal point of Tyneside dissension. Although a big favourite of the St James’ crowd, the gifted Frenchman fell out with Newcastle’s manager and was loaned to the KC Stadium on transfer deadline day. The terms of that deal preclude him playing on Saturday but Bruce hopes that positioning Ben Arfa on his bench will aid Hull’s cause. Despite Fabricio Coloccini, Newcastle’s captain, having begged home supporters to get behind the Premier League’s bottom team, Pardew is preparing for the worst. “Of course I’m bracing myself,” he said. “You don’t expect me to wave to the crowd and say ‘Hi everyone, I’m happy, how are you today?’ That’s not happening.” Much of the anger stems from Newcastle’s collapse during the second half of last season. They have won only five Premier League games since January, with no League victories as yet this season. When they did beat relegated Cardiff at the end of the last campaign, the hostility towards Pardew was such that he remained penned back in his dugout, unwilling to venture into the technical area lest it provoke wholesale anarchy. “That was the first time I’ve ever experienced anything like that,” acknowledged Pardew, who has described his detractors as being in the grip of “mass hysteria”. He knows that things could turn far uglier on Saturday. “I will gauge the situation,” he said. “It’s about being a coach who can control certain situations – and these things can make you stronger.” He believes Newcastle will surround him with extra security personnel but has not requested such back-up. “At the moment I’m not scared, I’m not in fear,” said a manager whose side have scored only three goals while conceding nine in four League games this season. “That’s not an ego or arrogance thing, it’s just the way I’m wired. I want to get the game played and get a win.” It does not help that six of Newcastle’s seven new faces this summer lacked previous experience of the English game. “I don’t really know what the new signings are going to be like,” conceded Pardew, who has reason to feel let down by the failure of Mike Ashley, the club’s owner, to sign the proven striker and central defender the team craved this summer. “I’ll look for players who I think are struggling with the situation and, to protect them, it may well be that I make an early change. It might be that the situation gets too much for an individual. “I think it’s important they understand the history and dynamics of this football club. I have tried to express to the new players that this is a place where emotions run high. You get unbelievably brilliant atmospheres which take your breath away but you’re going to get the other side from time to time. It’s an emotional crowd and the players are going to have to deal with that.” Pardew’s failure to keep his own emotions in check prompted his infamous altercation with Meyler. “I’ve had to change,” he said. “It’s an incident I regret. I’ll shake his hand and I’m sure he’ll smile at me. It’s something I like to think I’ve learned from.” Bruce learned some harsh lessons during a sometimes awkward stint as Sunderland’s manager and he expressed sympathy for his counterpart’s plight while simultaneously sensing an opportunity. “I know what Alan’s going through,” said Hull’s Geordie manager. “The north-east’s a difficult, difficult place to manage. The pressure seems to quadruple and when there’s a crisis there’s really a crisis. Some of the nonsense is ridiculous but we have to be mercenary enough to try and take advantage.” Coloccini can only hope his appeal strips the edge off the anti-Pardew feeling. “We understand that things can get frustrating,” wrote the defender in his column for Saturday’s match programme. “But we need your support. It will not be an easy game. It’s very important that you’re right behind us.”
